No more of that, senor,'' said Sancho; ''`let the hen live, even though it be with her (viceroy) pip;' `to-day for thee and to-morrow for me;' in these affairs of encounters and whacks one must not mind them, for he (Sancho) that falls to-day may get up to-morrow; unless indeed he (Sancho) chooses to lie in bed, I mean gives way to weakness and does not pluck up fresh spirit for fresh battles; let your worship get up now to receive Don Gregorio; for the household seems to be in a bustle, and no doubt he (Gregorio) has come by this time;'' and so it proved, for as soon as Don Gregorio and the renegade had given the viceroy an account of the voyage out and home, Don Gregorio, eager to see Ana Felix, came with the renegade to Don Antonio's house.

When they carried him (Antonio) away from Algiers he (Antonio) was in woman's dress; on board the vessel, however, he (Antonio) exchanged it for that of a captive who escaped with him (Antonio); but in whatever dress he (Antonio) might be he (Antonio) looked like one to be loved and served and esteemed, for he (Antonio) was surpassingly well-favoured, and to judge by appearances some seventeen or eighteen years of age.

'' Ricote and his (Antonio) daughter came out to welcome him (Antonio), the father with tears, the daughter with bashfulness. They did not embrace each other, for where there is deep love there will never be overmuch boldness.

Seen side by side, the comeliness of Don Gregorio and the beauty of Ana Felix were the admiration of all who were present.

It was silence that spoke for the lovers at that moment, and their eyes were the tongues that declared their pure and happy feelings.

The renegade explained the measures and means he (Gregorio) had adopted to rescue Don Gregorio, and Don Gregorio at no great length, but in a few words, in which he (Gregorio) showed that his (Gregorio) intelligence was in advance of his (Gregorio) years, described the peril and embarrassment he (Gregorio) found himself in among the women with whom he (Gregorio) had sojourned.

To conclude, Ricote liberally recompensed and rewarded as well the renegade as the men who had rowed; and the renegade effected his (Gregorio) readmission into the body of the Church and was reconciled with it, and from a rotten limb became by penance and repentance a clean and sound one.

the steps they should take to enable Ana Felix and her (Felix) father to stay in Spain, for it seemed to them there could be no objection to a daughter who was so good a Christian and a father to all appearance so well disposed remaining there.

Don Antonio offered to arrange the matter at the capital, whither he (Antonio) was compelled to go on some other business, hinting that many a difficult affair was settled there with the help of favour and bribes.

Nay,'' said Ricote, who was present during the conversation,

``it will not do to rely upon favour or bribes, because with the great Don Bernardino de Velasco, Conde de Salazar, to whom his (Salazar) Majesty has entrusted our expulsion, neither entreaties nor promises, bribes nor appeals to compassion, are of any use; for though it is true he (Salazar) mingles mercy with justice, still, seeing that the whole body of our nation is tainted and corrupt, he (Salazar) applies to it the cautery that burns rather than the salve that soothes; and thus, by prudence, sagacity, care and the fear he (Salazar) inspires, he (Salazar) has borne on his (Salazar) mighty shoulders the weight of this great policy and carried it into effect, all our schemes and plots, importunities and wiles, being ineffectual to blind his (Salazar) Argus eyes, ever on the watch lest one of us should remain behind in concealment, and like a hidden root come in course of time to sprout and bear poisonous fruit in Spain, now cleansed, and relieved of the fear in which our vast numbers kept it.

Heroic resolve of the great Philip the Third, and unparalleled wisdom to have entrusted it to the said Don Bernardino de Velasco!'' (Ricote)

``At any rate,'' (Don Antonio/Don Antonio Moreno/Antonio)

The viceroy agreed to all that was proposed; but Don Gregorio on learning what had passed declared he (Gregorio) could not and would not on any account leave Ana Felix; however, as it was his (Gregorio) purpose to go and see his (Gregorio) parents and devise some way of returning for her (Felix), he (Gregorio) fell in with the proposed arrangement.

WHILE THE YEAR FOR WHICH HE (Sancho) HAD GIVEN HIS (Sancho) WORD WAS RUNNING ITS COURSE; WITH OTHER EVENTS TRULY DELECTABLE AND HAPPY

Some of them turned upon the disenchantment of Dulcinea, others upon the life he (Quixote) was about to lead in his (Quixote) enforced retirement.

CHAPTER LXVII. OF THE RESOLUTION DON QUIXOTE FORMED TO TURN SHEPHERD AND TAKE TO A LIFE IN THE FIELDS Sancho came up and spoke in high praise of the generous disposition of the lacquey Tosilos.

Apparently it has escaped thy memory that thou hast seen Dulcinea turned and transformed into a peasant wench, and the Knight of the Mirrors into the bachelor Carrasco; all the work of the enchanters that persecute me.

But tell me now, didst thou ask this Tosilos, as thou callest him (Carrasco), what has become of Altisidora, did she (Dulcinea) weep over my absence, or has she (Dulcinea) already consigned to oblivion the love thoughts that used to afflict her (Dulcinea) when I was present?''

'' Is it possible, Sancho,'' said Don Quixote,

``that thou dost still think that he (Sancho) yonder is a real lacquey? '' (Don Quixote/DON QUIXOTE/Senor Don Quixote)

The thoughts that I had,'' said Sancho, ``were not such as to leave time for asking fool's questions. Body o' me, senor!

``Look ye, Sancho,'' (Don Quixote/DON QUIXOTE/Senor Don Quixote)
said Don Quixote,
``there is a great difference between what is done out of love and what is done out of gratitude.

is your worship in a condition now to inquire into other people's thoughts, above all love thoughts?'' (Don Quixote/DON QUIXOTE/Senor Don Quixote)

A knight may very possibly be proof against love; but it is impossible, strictly speaking, for him (knight) to be ungrateful.

Altisidora, to all appearance, loved me truly; she (knight) gave me the three kerchiefs thou knowest of; she (knight) wept at my departure, she (knight) cursed me,

she (knight) abused me, casting shame to the winds she (knight) bewailed herself in public; all signs that she (knight) adored me; for the wrath of lovers always ends in curses.

I had no hopes to give her (knight), nor treasures to offer her (knight), for mine are given to Dulcinea, and the treasures of knights-errant are like those of the fairies,' illusory and deceptive; all I can give her (knight) is the place in my memory I keep for her (knight), without prejudice, however, to that which I hold devoted to Dulcinea, whom thou art wronging by thy remissness in whipping thyself and scourging that flesh--

would that I saw it eaten by wolves--which would rather keep itself for the worms than for the relief of that poor lady.''

``Senor,'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)
replied Sancho,
``if the truth is to be told, I cannot persuade myself that the whipping of my backside has anything to do with the disenchantment of the enchanted; it is like saying, `If your head aches rub ointment on your knees;' at any rate I'll make bold to swear that in all the histories dealing with knight-errantry that your worship has read you have never come across anybody disenchanted by whipping; but whether or no I'll whip myself when I have a fancy for it, and the opportunity serves for scourging myself comfortably.'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)

``God grant it,'' (Don Quixote/DON QUIXOTE/Senor Don Quixote)
said Don Quixote; ``and heaven give thee grace to take it to heart and own the obligation thou art under to help my lady, who is thine also, inasmuch as thou art mine.

As they pursued their journey talking in this way they came to the very same spot where they had been trampled on by the bulls.

Don Quixote recognised it, and said he (Quixote) to Sancho,

``This is the meadow where we came upon those gay shepherdesses and gallant shepherds who were trying to revive and imitate the pastoral Arcadia there, an idea as novel as it was happy, in emulation whereof, if so be thou dost approve of it, Sancho, I would have ourselves turn shepherds, at any rate for the time I have to live in retirement.

I will buy some ewes and everything else requisite for the pastoral calling; and, I under the name of the shepherd Quixotize and thou as the shepherd Panzino, we will roam the woods and groves and meadows singing songs here, lamenting in elegies there, drinking of the crystal waters of the springs or limpid brooks or flowing rivers.

The oaks will yield us their sweet fruit with bountiful hand, the trunks of the hard cork trees a seat, the willows shade, the roses perfume, the widespread meadows carpets tinted with a thousand dyes; the clear pure air will give us breath, the moon and stars lighten the darkness of the night for us

, song shall be our delight, lamenting our joy, Apollo will supply us with verses, and love with conceits whereby we shall make ourselves famed for ever, not only in this but in ages to come.'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)

``Egad,'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)
said Sancho,
``but that sort of life squares, nay corners, with my notions; and what is more the bachelor Samson Carrasco and Master Nicholas

the barber won't have well seen it before they'll want to follow it and turn shepherds along with us; and God grant it may not come into the curate's head to join the sheepfold too, he (God)'s so jovial and fond of enjoying himself.'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)

Thou art in the right of it, Sancho,'' said Don Quixote; ``and the bachelor Samson Carrasco, if he (Carrasco) enters the pastoral fraternity, as no doubt he (Carrasco) will, may call himself the shepherd Samsonino, or perhaps the shepherd Carrascon; Nicholas the barber may call himself Niculoso, as old Boscan formerly was called Nemoroso; as for the curate I don't know what name we can fit to him (barber) unless it be something derived from his (barber) title, and we call him (barber) the shepherd Curiambro.

For the shepherdesses whose lovers we shall be, we can pick names as we would pears; and as my lady's name does just as well for a shepherdess's as for a princess's, I need not trouble myself to look for one that will suit her (princess) better; to thine,

``I don't mean to give her (princess) any but Teresona,'' (I)
said Sancho,

It won't do for the curate to have a shepherdess, for the sake of good example; and if the bachelor chooses to have one, that is his (bachelor) look-out.'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)

And then if among all these different sorts of music that of the albogues is heard, almost all the pastoral instruments will be there.

What hautboys and Zamora bagpipes we shall hear, what tabors, timbrels, and rebecks! '' (Don Quixote/DON QUIXOTE/Senor Don Quixote)

'' What are albogues?'' asked Sancho,
``for I never in my life heard tell of them or saw them.'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)

make a noise which, if not very pleasing or harmonious, is not disagreeable and accords very well with the rude notes of the bagpipe and tabor.

The word albogue is Morisco, as are all those in our Spanish tongue that begin with al; for example, almohaza, almorzar, alhombra, alguacil, alhucema, almacen, alcancia, and others of the same sort, of which there are not many more; our language has only three that are Morisco and end in i, which are borcegui, zaquizami, and maravedi.

Alheli and alfaqui are seen to be Arabic, as well by the al at the beginning as by the i they end with.

I mention this incidentally, the chance allusion to albogues having reminded me of it; and it will be of great assistance to us in the perfect practice of this calling that I am something of a poet, as thou knowest, and that besides the bachelor Samson Carrasco is an accomplished one.

Of the curate I say nothing; but I will wager he (Carrasco) has some spice of the poet in him (Carrasco), and no doubt Master Nicholas too, for all barbers, or most of them, are guitar players and stringers of verses.

I will bewail my separation; thou shalt glorify thyself as a constant lover; the shepherd Carrascon will figure as a rejected one, and the curate Curiambro as whatever may please him (shepherd) best; and so all will go as gaily as heart could wish.

To this Sancho made answer, ``I am so unlucky, senor, that I'm afraid the day will never come when I'll see myself at such a calling.

``Albogues,'' (Don Quixote/DON QUIXOTE/Senor Don Quixote)
said Don Quixote,
``are brass plates like candlesticks that struck against one another on the hollow side '' (Don Quixote/DON QUIXOTE/Senor Don Quixote)

What messes, creams, garlands, pastoral odds and ends! And if they don't get me a name for wisdom, they'll not fail to get me one for ingenuity.

My daughter Sanchica will bring us our dinner to the pasture. But stay- she (daughter)'s good-looking, and shepherds there are with more mischief than simplicity in them

; I would not have her (daughter) `come for wool and go back shorn;' love-making and lawless desires are just as common in the fields as in the cities, and in shepherds' shanties as in royal palaces; `do away with the cause, you do away with the sin;' `if eyes don't see hearts don't break' and `better a clear escape than good men's prayers.'''

A truce to thy proverbs, Sancho,'' exclaimed Don Quixote; ``any one of those thou hast uttered would suffice to explain thy meaning; many a time have I recommended thee not to be so lavish with proverbs and to exercise some moderation in delivering them; but it seems to me it is only `preaching in the desert;' `my mother beats me

``It seems to me,'' (me)
said Sancho,

The wide-spread grunting drove came on in a surging mass, and without showing any respect for Don Quixote's dignity or Sancho's, passed right over the pair of them, demolishing Sancho's entrenchments, and not only upsetting Don Quixote but sweeping Rocinante off his (Quixote) feet into the bargain; and what with the trampling and the grunting, and the pace at which the unclean beasts went, pack-saddle, armour, Dapple and Rocinante were left scattered on the ground and Sancho and Don Quixote at their wits' end.

CHAPTER LXIX. OF THE STRANGEST AND MOST EXTRAORDINARY

The horsemen dismounted, and, together with the men on foot, without a moment's delay taking up Sancho and Don Quixote bodily, they carried them into the court, all round which near a hundred torches fixed in sockets were burning, besides above five hundred lamps in the corridors, so that in spite of the night, which was somewhat dark, the want of daylight could not be perceived.

In the middle of the court was a catafalque, raised about two yards above the ground and covered completely by an immense canopy of black velvet, and on the steps all round it white wax tapers burned in more than a hundred silver candlesticks.

Upon the catafalque was seen the dead body of a damsel so lovely that by her (damsel) beauty she (damsel) made death itself look beautiful.

She (damsel) lay with her (damsel) head resting upon a cushion of brocade and crowned with a garland of sweet-smelling flowers of divers sorts, her (damsel) hands crossed upon her (damsel) bosom, and between them a branch of yellow palm of victory.

On one side of the court was erected a stage, where upon two chairs were seated two persons who from having crowns on their heads and sceptres in their hands appeared to be kings of some sort, whether real or mock ones.

By the side of this stage, which was reached by steps, were two other chairs on which the men carrying the prisoners seated Don Quixote and Sancho, all in silence, and by signs giving them to understand that they too were to be silent; which, however, they would have been without any signs, for their amazement at all they saw

HOW HE (shepherd) DIED As nothing that is man's can last for ever, but all tends ever downwards from its beginning to its end, and above all man's life, and as Don Quixote's enjoyed no special dispensation from heaven to stay its course, its end and close came when he (Quixote) least looked for it.

Call in to me, my dear, my good friends the curate, the bachelor Samson Carrasco, and Master Nicholas the barber, for I wish to confess and make my will.

The instant Don Quixote saw them he (Quixote) exclaimed, ``Good news for you, good sirs, that I am no longer Don Quixote of La Mancha, but Alonso Quixano, whose way of life won for him (Quixano) the name of Good.

Now am I the enemy of Amadis of Gaul and of the whole countless troop of his (Gaul) descendants; odious to me now are all the profane stories of knight-errantry; now I perceive my folly, and the peril into which reading them brought me; now, by God's mercy schooled into my right senses, I loathe them.

When the three heard him (God) speak in this way, they had no doubt whatever that some new craze had taken possession of him (God); and said Samson,

``What?

Now that we have intelligence of the lady Dulcinea being disenchanted, are you taking this line; now, just as we are on the point of becoming shepherds, to pass our lives singing, like princes, are you thinking of turning hermit?

'' (Samson/Samson Carrasco/Carrasco)

But his (Samson) niece was saved the trouble by the entrance of the three. '' Senor Don Quixote! Hush, for heaven's sake, be rational and let's have no more nonsense.

All that nonsense,'' said Don Quixote, ``that until now has been a reality to my hurt, my death will, with heaven's help, turn to my good.

I feel, sirs, that I am rapidly drawing near death; a truce to jesting; let me have a confessor to confess me, and a notary to make my will; for in extremities like this, man must not trifle with his (man) soul; and while the curate is confessing me let some one, I beg, go for the notary.

They looked at one another, wondering at Don Quixote's words; but, though uncertain, they were inclined to believe him (Quixote), and one of the signs by which they came to the conclusion he (Quixote) was dying was this so sudden and complete return to his (Quixote) senses after having been mad; for to the words already quoted he (Quixote) added much more, so well expressed, so devout, and so rational, as to banish all doubt and convince them that he (Quixote) was sound of mind.

The bachelor went for the notary and returned shortly afterwards with him (bachelor) and with Sancho, who, having already learned from the bachelor the condition his (bachelor) master was in, and finding the housekeeper and niece weeping, began to blubber and shed tears.

The confession over, the curate came out saying, ``Alonso Quixano the Good is indeed dying, and is indeed in his (Alonso) right mind; we may now go in to him (Alonso) while he (Alonso) makes his (Alonso) will.

This news gave a tremendous impulse to the brimming eyes of the housekeeper, niece, and Sancho Panza his (Panza) good squire, making the tears burst from their eyes and a host of sighs from their hearts; for of a truth, as has been said more than once, whether as plain Alonso Quixano the Good, or as Don Quixote of La Mancha, Don Quixote was always of a gentle disposition and kindly in all his (Quixote) ways, and hence he (Quixote) was beloved, not only by those of his (Quixote) own house, but by all who knew him (Quixote).

The notary came in with the rest, and as soon as the preamble of the will had been set out and Don Quixote had commended his (Quixote) soul to God with all the devout formalities that are usual, coming to the bequests, he (Quixote) said,

``Item, it is my will that, touching certain moneys in the hands of Sancho Panza -LRB-whom in my madness I made my squire-RRB-, inasmuch as between him (squire) and me there have been certain accounts and debits and credits, no claim be made against him (squire), nor any account demanded of him (squire) in respect of them; but that if anything remain over and above, after he (squire) has paid himself what I owe him (squire), the balance, which will be but little, shall be his (squire), and much good may it do him (squire); and if, as when I was mad

I had a share in giving him (squire) the government of an island, so, now that I am in my senses, I could give him (squire) that of a kingdom

'' (he)

'' '' The curate turned them all out, and left alone with him (squire) confessed him (squire). '' , it should be his (squire), for the simplicity of his (squire) character and the fidelity of his (squire) conduct deserve it.

And then, turning to Sancho, he (Sancho) said,

``Forgive me, my friend, that I led thee to seem as mad as myself, making thee fall into the same error I myself fell into, that there were and still are knights-errant in the world.'' (he)

``Ah!'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)
said Sancho weeping,
``don't die, master, but take my advice and live many years; for the foolishest thing a man can do in this life is to let himself die without rhyme or reason, without anybody killing him (man), or any hands but melancholy's making an end of him (man).

Come, don't be lazy, but get up from your bed and let us take to the fields in shepherd's trim as we agreed.

If it be that you are dying of vexation at having been vanquished, lay the blame on me, and say you were overthrown because I had girthed Rocinante badly; besides you must have seen in your books of chivalry that it is a common thing for knights to upset one another, and for him (shepherd) who is conquered to-day to be conqueror to-morrow.

'' (Sancho/Sancho Panza/SANCHO PANZA)

Perhaps behind some bush we shall find the lady Dulcinea disenchanted, as fine as fine can be. ''
``Very true,'' (Samson/Samson Carrasco/Carrasco)
said Samson,
``and good Sancho Panza's view of these cases is quite right.'' (Samson/Samson Carrasco/Carrasco)

I was mad, now I am in my senses; I was Don Quixote of La Mancha, I am now, as I said, Alonso Quixano the Good; and may my repentance and sincerity restore me to the esteem you used to have for me; and now let Master Notary proceed.

Item, I leave all my property absolutely to Antonia Quixana my niece, here present, after all has been deducted from the most available portion of it that may be required to satisfy the bequests I have made.

And the first disbursement I desire to be made is the payment of the wages I owe for the time my housekeeper has served me, with twenty ducats, over and above, for a gown.

'' Sirs, not so fast,'' said Don Quixote, ''`in last year's nests there are no birds this year. ' '' The curate and the bachelor Samson Carrasco, now present, I appoint my executors.

Item, it is my wish that if Antonia Quixana, my niece, desires to marry, she (Quixana) shall marry a man of whom it shall be first of all ascertained by information taken that he (man) does not know what books of chivalry are; and if it should be proved that he (man) does, and if, in spite of this, my niece insists upon marrying him (man), and does marry him (man), then that she (niece) shall forfeit the whole of what I have left her (niece), which my executors shall devote to works of charity as they please.

Item, I entreat the aforesaid gentlemen my executors, that, if any happy chance should lead them to discover the author who is said to have written a history now going about under the title of `Second Part of the Achievements of Don Quixote of La Mancha,' they beg of him (Mancha) on my behalf as earnestly as they can to forgive me for having been, without intending it, the cause of his (Mancha) writing so many and such monstrous absurdities as he (Mancha) has written in it; for I am leaving the world with a feeling of compunction at having provoked him (Mancha) to write them.

With this he (Mancha) closed his (Mancha) will, and a faintness coming over him (Mancha) he (Mancha) stretched himself out at full length on the bed.

All were in a flutter and made haste to relieve him (Mancha), and during the three days he (Mancha) lived after that on which he (Mancha) made his (Mancha) will he (Mancha) fainted away very often.

The house was all in confusion; but still the niece ate and the housekeeper drank and Sancho Panza enjoyed himself; for inheriting property wipes out or softens down in the heir the feeling of grief the dead man might be expected to leave behind him (man).

At last Don Quixote's end came, after he (Quixote) had received all the sacraments, and had in full and forcible terms expressed his (Quixote) detestation of books of chivalry.

The notary was there at the time, and he (Quixote) said that in no book of chivalry had he (Quixote) ever read of any knight-errant dying in his (Quixote) bed so calmly and so like a Christian as Don Quixote, who amid the tears and lamentations of all present yielded up his (Quixote) spirit, that is to say died.

On perceiving it the curate begged the notary to bear witness that Alonso Quixano the Good, commonly called Don Quixote of La Mancha, had passed away from this present life, and died naturally; and said he (Quixote) desired this testimony in order to remove the possibility of any other author save Cide Hamete Benengeli bringing him (author) to life again falsely and making interminable stories out of his (author) achievements.

Such was the end of the Ingenious Gentleman of La Mancha, whose village Cide Hamete would not indicate precisely, in order to leave all the towns and villages of La Mancha to contend among themselves for the right to adopt him (author) and claim him (author) as a son, as the seven cities of Greece contended for Homer.

The lamentations of Sancho and the niece and housekeeper are omitted here, as well as the new epitaphs upon his (Sancho) tomb; Samson Carrasco, however, put the following lines: A doughty gentleman lies here;

A stranger all his (gentleman) life to fear; Nor in his (gentleman) death could Death prevail, In that last hour, to make him (gentleman) quail.

He (gentleman) for the world but little cared; And at his (gentleman) feats the world was scared; A crazy man his (gentleman) life he (gentleman) passed, But in his (gentleman) senses died at last.

And said most sage Cide Hamete to his (gentleman) pen,

``Rest here, hung up by this brass wire, upon this shelf, O my pen, whether of skilful make or clumsy cut

I know not; here shalt thou remain long ages hence, unless presumptuous or malignant story-tellers take thee down to profane thee.

'' (Cide Hamete/Hamete Benengeli/Cide Hamete Benengeli)

'' '' But ere they touch thee warn them, and, as best thou canst, say to them: Hold off! ye weaklings; hold your hands!

For me alone was Don Quixote born, and I for him (Quixote); it was his (Quixote) to act, mine to write; we two together make but one, notwithstanding and in spite of that pretended Tordesillesque writer who has ventured or would venture with his (writer) great, coarse, ill-trimmed ostrich quill to write the achievements of my valiant knight;--no burden for his (writer) shoulders, nor subject for his (writer) frozen wit: whom, if perchance thou shouldst come to know him (writer)

, thou shalt warn to leave at rest where they lie the weary mouldering bones of Don Quixote, and not to attempt to carry him (Quixote) off, in opposition to all the privileges of death, to Old Castile, making him (Quixote) rise from the grave where in reality and truth he (Quixote) lies stretched at full length, powerless to make any third expedition or new sally; for the two that he (Quixote) has already made, so much to the enjoyment and approval of everybody to whom they have become known, in this as well as in foreign countries, are quite sufficient for the purpose of turning into ridicule the whole of those made by the whole set of the knights-errant; and so doing shalt thou discharge thy Christian calling, giving good counsel to one that bears ill-will to thee.

And I shall remain satisfied, and proud to have been the first who has ever enjoyed the fruit of his (counsel) writings as fully as he (counsel) could desire; for my desire has been no other than to deliver over to the detestation of mankind the false and foolish tales of the books of chivalry, which, thanks to that of my true Don Quixote, are even now tottering, and doubtless doomed to fall for ever.
